title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) — On a night when defense reigned and shots clanged for nearly everyone else, Hakeem Olajuwon authored a masterpiece. The Houston Rockets’ legendary center delivered a performance of sheer, unadulterated dominance, carrying his team to a gritty 96-85 victory over the Sacramento Kings.

From the opening tip, this was the Hakeem Show. While teammates and opponents alike struggled to find an offensive rhythm, Olajuwon was a model of relentless efficiency. He was an unstoppable force in the paint, a whirlwind of dream shakes and turnaround jumpers that the Kings had no answer for. When the final buzzer sounded, the stat sheet told a story of historic proportions: a game-high 42 points, a monstrous 22 rebounds, and 4 blocked shots. He didn't just fill the box score; he overwhelmed it.

Sacramento, led by Mitch Richmond's 21 points, fought valiantly but was simply overmatched by the one-man wrecking crew. Every run the Kings attempted was met with a thunderous Olajuwon bucket or a critical defensive stop from the Rockets' anchor. Clyde Drexler provided crucial support with 17 points, but this night belonged to one man.

Olajuwon’s 42-point, 22-rebound tour de force was more than just a win; it was a reminder of his place among the game's pantheon of greats. In an era defined by its big men, "The Dream" proved, once again, that on any given night, he could be the most dominant force on the planet.
